name: Seoul
fun_fact: Fun fact: Seoul is home to Mosu, Korea's only three-Michelin-star restaurant, but locals are just as passionate about Gwangjang Market's street food stalls that have been serving the same families for over 100 years - proving that culinary excellence exists at every price point.

hero_dishes.name: Bibimbap
hero_dishes.description: Korean mixed rice with colorful seasoned vegetables, gochujang (chili paste), meat, and a raw or fried egg, served in a sizzling hot stone bowl
hero_dishes.origin_story: This iconic Korean dish represents harmony and balance - each ingredient maintains its distinct flavor while creating a perfect whole when mixed together. The hot stone bowl creates crispy rice at the bottom (nurungji), the most prized part
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Jeonju Yuhalmeoni Bibimbap (Grandma Yu's - over 40 years old, most authentic in Seoul)

hero_dishes.name: Seoul-Style Bulgogi
hero_dishes.description: Thinly-sliced beef marinated in soy sauce, sugar, sesame oil, garlic, and pear, then grilled to caramelized perfection
hero_dishes.origin_story: Seoul's version of bulgogi is so popular that Bib Gourmand restaurant Wooraeok has customers willing to wait several hours for a table. The secret is in the marinade and the quality of the beef
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Wooraeok (Bib Gourmand - prepare to wait hours), traditional Korean BBQ restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Chutang (Seoul-Style Loach Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Spicy soup made with whole boiled loach in a broth of beef bones, brisket, and intestines, seasoned with red chili powder
hero_dishes.origin_story: This distinctly Seoul specialty is unique to the capital. The soup is rich, spicy, and considered a stamina food that gives energy and vitality
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Yonggeumok (Bib Gourmand restaurant specializing in this Seoul classic)

hero_dishes.name: North Korean-Style Mandu (Dumplings)
hero_dishes.description: Handmade dumplings with a traditional family recipe brought from North Korea - delicate wrappers with flavorful meat and vegetable filling
hero_dishes.origin_story: At Gaeseong Mandu Koong in Insadong, the family includes someone who escaped from North Korea. They've been making dumplings with their traditional recipe for three generations
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gaeseong Mandu Koong (Insadong - 3-generation family recipe from North Korea)

signature_drinks.name: Soju
signature_drinks.description: Korea's national spirit - a clear distilled liquor traditionally made from rice
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed with Korean BBQ and fried chicken, always poured for others (never yourself) as a sign of respect. The youngest person at the table pours for elders

signature_drinks.name: Makgeolli
signature_drinks.description: Milky, slightly sweet rice wine with a low alcohol content - refreshing and fizzy
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Traditionally served in brass bowls and paired with pajeon (savory pancakes) on rainy days. It's making a comeback among young Koreans

food_culture_notes: Gwangjang Market (established 1905) is one of Seoul's oldest traditional markets with over 5,000 shops
Street food costs between 1,000-4,000 KRW (US$0.70-3) and is filling enough for a meal
Korean meals always include banchan (side dishes) that are refilled for free - kimchi is mandatory
Eatanic Garden at Josun Palace Hotel serves Michelin-starred innovative Korean cuisine focused on fermented and aged flavors

atmosphere: neon signs and street food steam
unique_modern: three-Michelin-star restaurants next to 100-year-old market stalls
